BAE 495/590: Applied Statistics for Environmental and Agricultural Data Analysis


Statistics BAE 495/590 (Applied Statistics for Environmental and Agricultural Data Analysis) is a course designed for undergraduate and graduate students who need to diligently apply the proper statistical methodology to solve real-world problems in environmental and agricultural fields. Fundamental and practical statistical concepts are covered and are employed in several areas of application. Students will also manage and analyze data by coding in R, an open-source programming language. This course was elaborated by compiling free references and public data sources and offers all the materials needed to students.


Learning outcomes

Upon completion of the course, students will have the following knowledge and skills:

  • Demonstrate a deep understanding and usage of basic statistical concepts.
  • Evaluate and interpret findings on environmental/agricultural system dynamics through fundamental statistical analyses of environmental/agricultural data.
  • Demonstrate their ability to synthesize information and conclusions of analysis in written reports.
  • Produce R code for data management, analysis, and visualization.


Teaching philosophy of the course



The students will be taught statistics using real datasets to solve agricultural and environmental problems. Real-world examples and datasets requiring R programming will be used to test and implement basic statistical analysis concepts. We believe that this approach will help students to incorporate statistics into their general education curriculum.










Importance of statistics in engineering and environmental fields

Statistics is a branch of mathematics science that collect, analyze, and make inferences from data. Statistics is the core of many areas in agricultural and environmental sciences that involve research and decision-making. This science is used to communicate and interpret findings from data analysis. Statistics can be seen as a tool that supports hypothesis and gives credibility to the methodology used. Statistics in agricultural and environmental sciences covers several types of study:

  • Analyse the present state of resources (e.g., harvested crops, livestock assessment).
  • Identify anomalies (e.g., air quality change, groundwater contamination).
  • Test hypothesis using observed data.
  • Perform estimations of parameters and predictions.



Use of real world data

Artificial and synthetic data are often used to demonstrate statistical concepts and methods in traditional statistics course. Artificial data are often idealized and composed of few values that are not representative of real datasets. This teaching approach does not confront students in the context of real-world problems and questions. The course aims to fill this gap by using only real-world datasets. These data help students to understand why and how statistics are applied to a real-world context.

Use of R

Real-world datasets are often composed of thousands of data that does not allow students to compute statistical calculi by hand or by calculi spreadsheet. Statistical software was developed to decrease the computing time and the tedious of computations. For the course, RStudio will be used. RStudio is a free and open-source integrated development environment (IDE) for R that is a programming language for statistical computing and graphics. R is gaining in popularity and can handle large and complex data. This program is well-maintained, updated, and supported making it reliable. This software can be downloaded here.

Real-world data are often not ready to be used directly and need to be manipulated before conducting analyses. With RStudio, students will:

  • Understand the structure of the datasets used.
  • Arrange and manage data.
  • Perform visualizations.
  • Explore data analysis.
